Name: DOC
Definition: Denominazione di Origine Controllata – an Italian wine classification that guarantees the wine’s origin and adherence to specific production regulations.

Name: DOCG
Definition: Denominazione di Origine Controllata e Garantita – Italy’s highest classification for wines, ensuring stricter quality controls and tasting evaluations.

Name: Piemonte
Definition: A renowned wine-producing region in northwest Italy, known for Barolo, Barbaresco, and other high-quality wines made from Nebbiolo, Barbera, and Dolcetto.

Name: Body
Definition:
Describes the weight and fullness of the wine in your mouth. Light-bodied wines feel more like water; full-bodied wines feel more like milk or cream.
Light-bodied wines are refreshing and low in alcohol (e.g., Pinot Grigio, Beaujolais).
Medium-bodied wines strike a balance in weight and character (e.g., Merlot, Chardonnay).
Full-bodied wines feel rich and substantial, often with higher alcohol (e.g., Cabernet Sauvignon, oaked Chardonnay).

Name: Tannins
Definition: Naturally occurring compounds found in grape skins, seeds, and stems that give red wines their astringency, structure, and aging potential.

Name: Finish
Definition:
Refers to the lingering impression or aftertaste a wine leaves after swallowing.
A short finish fades quickly, a medium finish lingers briefly, a long finish denotes complexity and quality, and a very long finish indicates exceptional structure and aging potential.

Name: Acidity
Definition:
Natural acids in wine contribute to freshness, balance, aging potential, and food pairing compatibility.
Low acidity wines are soft, moderate acidity wines are balanced, and high acidity wines are crisp and vibrant, often with citrusy or tart notes.

Name: Sweetness
Definition: Determined by residual sugar after fermentation. Dry wines have little to no sugar, off-dry wines have a slight sweetness, and sweet wines have notable sugar levels, often found in dessert wines like Port or Sauternes.

Name: Aroma and Flavor
Definition: Fruity, floral, vegetal, spicy, earthy, mineral, oak, and nutty notes are typical. Secondary aromas may include creamy, brioche, or lactic tones, while aging adds cedar, leather, tobacco, or petrol.
